And therefore it is that in reading Ᾰ Kempis the Christian conscience feels itself in the moral atmosphere of the Gospels. There are here no such accommoda- tions of the words of Christ to moral situations which they cannot be made to sanction without more or less violence, as are to be met with in modern books of devotion3 and we pass from his pages to those of the inspired Evangelists with less sense of a change of spiritual atmosphere than is possible in the case of any other writer.
